children.value: "Diapers are so expensive!!" Most new parents hear this so many times when they're preparing for their first baby. Seasoned parents also lament diaper costs. If there's one thing every baby needs - it's diapers: this is one baby expense you can't really skip on.
But how much do they really cost? Here's what the Internet has to say about disposable diaper costs in a baby's first year:

Low end: Parent's Choice. High end: Honest. Pampers was in the middle ($~700). 11-38 cents/diaper. Calculated number of diapers based on time 50th percentile baby will be in each size and number diapers per day by diaper size.
Low end: Up&Up. High end: Pampers. Calculated number of diapers based on time 50th percentile baby will be in each size and number diapers per day by diaper.
2057 diapers, Pampers Cruisers, ~25 cents/diaper. Doesn't include wipes/diaper bin (~$825 with those).
$60 for first month (10 diapers/day, 20 cents/diaper) and $48/month after that
also used the same estimate of $75/month

Some of these numbers are quite large! We spent $75/month on restaurants in 2020 - did our diaper spending really equal that of our eating out (for two adults) splurges? What did we really spend on diapering in our first year?
Grand total for diapers and wipes in the first year: ~$196 = $16/month = $4/week
This is way lower than most estimates... Why?

that we used ~1620 diapers in the first year, or ~4.45/day. This includes diapers purchased or given to us. More on this later, but this number passes a basic sanity check for our little guy - we probably go through about 4 diapers a day now (and have for quite some time), but newborns need diapers almost every time they feed (~6-8 times/day).
432 total, purchased 240 ($23.20 - 10.3 cents/diaper), 192 Costco hand-me-downs from friends (charged at 10.3 cents/diaper = $19.86)
342 total, purchased 184 ($21.99 - 11.95 cents/diaper), ~158 gifted (charged at 11.95 cents/diaper = $18.88)
Year 2 costs for diapers/wipes should remain close to this - although bigger sizes are more expensive, baby also needs fewer diapers per day.

People are generous - they like to buy things for your baby. Diapers are popular gifts (after all, every baby needs them), and we're grateful for the gifts we received. We also ended up with a few diapers that other babies had grown out of before they finished a box. For any diapers we didn't pay for ourselves, I

include these in my calculations - counting them as used and assuming they had the same cost per diaper as other diapers of the same size. We received ~$38.74 of free diapers, so we only actually spent $157.20 on diapers for baby's first year, and honestly, much of this was covered by gift cards from the baby shower our friends and family insisted on throwing for us.
Apparently 1620 diapers in the first year is fewer than most places on the Internet suggest: we used 55-80% of the estimated necessary diapers.
Is our baby just a wonder-child?
Are we mistreating our son by letting him sit in his diapers too long?
Maybe a little bit of the first three.
I didn't keep incredibly detailed track of all of the free diapers we recieved, but I don't think I missed over 400 free diapers.
Every baby is different. Our little guy:
Doesn't complain about his diaper being wet/dirty and only occasionally gets diaper rash (usually while sleeping).
Started sleeping long stretches fairly early (3-4 months), and babies soil fewer diapers when they're sleeping. Note that

suggests changing diapers every 3 hours (or on-demand, which we definitely do for stinky or noticabley wet diapers). He's slept 10+ hours/night since he was 4 months old, so that's only 4-5 diapers/day. So it's not crazy.
Is ~20th percentile for weight, so even at 18 months he was 23 lbs - solidly in the size 3 diapers.
Has a regular amount of bowel movements: at least daily (more when he was younger).

While we may have lower diaper usage than many families, 3000 diapers is 8.2 diapers per day and while that may have been realistic for the first few months, I can't imagine using that many per day after he started solid foods. I never saw any direct source data for these recommended ranges, so it's hard to know where they come from. My best guess is from diaper manufacturers, like this

, which suggests between 1900-2900 diapers in the first year. However, stretching diapers to the point where it causes rashes, UTIs, or discomfort is certainly not recommended - some babies scream when even a dot of blue can be seen on the wetness indicator.

properties.ariaLabel: how often should you change a babys diaper permalink

children.value: How often should you change a baby's diaper?

, which tests urine samples of 2 month-2.5 yr olds who had fevers of above 100.4°F for UTIs. The group without UTIs had 7.5 ± 1.4 diaper changes/day, and the group with UTIs had 4.7 ± 1.4 diaper changes/day. So there is some evidence that changing a diaper more often can decrease UTIs (among infants with a fever who were tested). We don't think our little man has ever gotten a UTI (he is basically never sick - thanks COVID for keeping us home all the time).
These days (18 months), here is our general diaper changing philosophy... Little man always gets a new diaper:
When he wakes up in the morning.

He also gets a new diaper whenever it's dirty, or when we notice his diaper is full. Or if he's particularly cranky. We also change it more frequently if it looks like some diaper rash is coming on. Half the days, only the waking up diaper is dirty, but usually there is a mid-morning or early evening dirty diaper. We end up using 4-5 diapers most days.
We also have a baby boy - I wonder if baby girls have different diaper soiling patterns, or if you need to change them more often because biology.

properties.ariaLabel: what if my baby really does need that many diapers permalink

children.value: What if my baby really does need that many diapers?

kept more detailed notes than me, and changed 2057 diapers in the first year. 437 more diapers than we used at ~11 cents/diaper + 2 cents/wipe/diaper would bring our costs for diapers/wipes to $196 + $57 = $253/year. This is about $1 more/week. She spent about double the amount we would have (based on cost/diaper) than we would have ($253 vs. $505).
If we had used 3000 diapers, we would have used 1380 more diapers, and at 11 cents/diaper + 2 cents/wipe/diaper we would have spent $179 more. This would bring our costs to $375/year.
Here's a summary of that data, assuming 11 cents/diaper + 2 cents/wipe/diaper for diapers over the 1620 diapers we actually used:
High End of Recommended Diaper Range
So... our low usage helps, but even if we used 3000 diapers in the first year, it doesn't explain the roughly 2x gap between $31/month and the typically estimated $75/month.
As we (apparently) are a bit stingy with our diapers, we are also stingy with our wipes: most wet diapers don't get a wipe; most dirty diapers get 1-2

. There are obvious blowout "3 wiper" exceptions (or emergency baths), and I imagine that with a baby girl instead of a boy, we'd wipe for every diaper, not just the dirty ones. I remember seeing a mom at mom's group use 5 wipes for what I would have deemd a "1 wiper", but to each his own - maybe her baby gets diaper rash really easily so it's worth the tradeoff.

But wipes aren't that expensive (~1.5 cents/diaper) so we're not really saving that much here. Using fewer wipes has the bigger benefit of not needing to change the wipes container as often, and therefore avoiding the "no more wipes in the container mid-diaper change" problem.

properties.ariaLabel: per diaper costs   a note on buying in bulk permalink

children.value: Per diaper costs - a note on buying in bulk

Every diaper purchase came down to calculating the per diaper cost. To repeat advice you read everywhere on the internet - buy in bulk! In many cases, buying the biggest box you can is the cheapest, but occasionally a smaller box is cheaper per diaper, or roughly equivalent. But of course, make sure you're going to be able to use all the diapers in the box before sizing up. In a few cases, the slight difference in cost per diaper of a small pack vs. a huge box is worth the flexibility. Our Size 2 diapers ended up being the most expensive per diaper because we bought a couple smaller packs to get us to the next size, but probably saved us $$ in the long run.

We did try to plan ahead - if we were nearing the end of a size, we'd try the next size up a couple of times to see if it would work or be leak-city so we could decide if we would be able use an entire new box, a small pack, or just move up a bit early. The weight ranges on the diaper sizes are just guidelines - reasonably good ones, but you know your baby best.
Target has some unique discounts that we were able to take advantage of with a little, but not a lot of, work - no coupon clipping or online shopping extensions necessary.
Target's REDcard gives you 5% off every purchase.

Target often (every couple of months) runs deals for "spend $100 on diapers, get a $20 gift card". This makes any diaper purchased at Target much cheaper: without REDCard ~20% off, depending on how close you can get to $100; with REDCard, the calculation is more complicated, but it's more than 20% off. Occasionally (2x/year or so), they do a $30 gift card for $100.
Most mainstream diaper brands are sold at Target. You can also easily return them if you don't open a box.

This requires your financial/storage space situation to allow for buying diapers several weeks (months?) before you might need them. The upside: we've never been close to running out of diapers - we're always buying a few weeks/months ahead of time, so there's no fighting about who was supposed to remember to buy them. I get a notification from the Target app about the $20 off $100 deal, and check our stash and replenish as necessary.
There are quite a few (disposable) diaper choices.

has an excellent analysis of many diaper brands, and concluded that Up&Up, Parent's Choice, and Pampers were worth their value, with Pampers earning the "Upgrade pick" for better-performing but also more expensive. They also concluded that eco-friendly diapers perform as well as Up&Up/Parent's Choice, but are 2-3x more expensive.

Our philosophy, as it is with many regular purchases, is to try a cheaper brand, and if it works, great, but if it doesn't, consider spending a little bit more for a higher quality product. We started with Up&Up diapers, and while there were some blowouts, we also had a few Pampers samples/gifts and they didn't seem to contain the mess any better. Our baby boy didn't have diaper rash - so they worked for us. In fact, we used a gifted box of Mickey Mouse themed Huggies, and anecdotally noticed more blowouts (granted, we were in Disney World, so lots of things were different).

If we had used a different brand, how much would we have paid for diapers? I took the prices from Target, Walmart, and Costco in Mar 2021, including any click-to-clip manufacturer's coupons and discounting all diapers/wipes you can buy at Target at 20%. Details in this
Costs for diapers and wipes, using actual amounts of sizes we used in the first year:
We saved $150 by using Up&Up diapers in 1 year, with no extra effort over buying Pampers from Target.
If you want eco-friendly diapers, you should decide if it's worth $300/year to do so.

) offer subscription services where diapers/wipes "magically" appear at your house on a regular schedule. This convenience may be worth it to your family. Suprisingly, if you prefer Hello Bello or Honest diapers, it's cheaper to get a subscription than it is to buy directly at Walmart/Target. Details in this
Caveat: You do need to better predict how many diapers of each size you'll need, as these diapers come in packs of ~200 every N weeks and you can't return them if you don't use them.

To properly handle diapers, there are a few things that make life easier. These don't seem be be included in other sites' estimates, so they're in a section by themselves here. Not all of these were necessary, as we equipped a secondary changing station that we used for baby's first ~4 months.
- garage sale, included enough liners for 1st year.
2 extra trash cans with lids for 2nd diaper stations

$15 lidded x2. Used these at secondary changing station and for wet-only diapers to reduce frequency of changing the diaper pail. They contain the smell enough for wet, but not solid-food dirty diapers.
- new in box at used baby sale, and one from
We had an extra backpack with lots of pockets that works well. We didn't find a dedicated diaper bag necessary, and there is room for lots of our things, toys, etc. as baby grows.

A notable exclusion is diaper cream. We got a couple of free sample tubes for creating registries at places like Target and Walmart, and we're still (18 months in) using those samples. Your pediatrician may also have free samples laying around. But diaper rash cream isn't really that expensive either - the brand our pediatrician recommends,

, is $4 for 2 oz (chepaer per ounce if your baby needs a giant tub of it). We also used (cheaper, less gross) petroleum jelly when our baby's bottom was tinged a bit pink and we were worried about it turning into something worse.
These could have cost us much more - for example, the Dekor Plus is $40 more than what we paid, and changing pad covers run 2 for ~$20.
Including these costs, plus diapers and wipes, we spent
for baby's first year of disposable diapering.
Year 2 (or baby 2) shouldn't have these start-up costs, although we will also need more diaper pail liners:
is working for us at $22 for ~1 year of liners.

We spent a lot less on diapers in the first year than most estimates suggest ($60-700 less). Our little guy apparently went through way fewer diapers than most infants (but was still very happy). But there was also a big difference in cost per diaper than most estimates (~11 cents/diaper vs. ~20 cents/diaper), mostly due to using the generic (non-eco friendly - gasp!) brand and shopping in bulk at 20% off sales.

Did I count every diaper and wipe? Of course not - I just kept track of how many boxes we went through (purchased or given to us). This number isn't perfect, but I think it's reasonably close. I didn't keep track of when we changed sizes, so I'm not sure how many newborn diapers per day we used - just an aggregate over the first year.

Sometimes I tear wipes in half to get the last little bits off, and leave half a wipe. My husband hates pulling out half a wipe. So sometimes we use 1.5 wipes per diaper, much to my husband's chagrin. Bigger kid diapers usually use 2 wipes.

frontmatter.title: Diapers
frontmatter.subtitle: Spoiler alert: they don't have to be that expensive
